files.name: OPENCLAW-UPDATE-GUIDE.md
files.content:
# OpenClaw Update Guide for Ubuntu
## How to Update Alex Prime Without Losing Settings

*Created: February 6, 2026*
*Author: Alex Prime*

---

## ðŸ“‹ Pre-Update Checklist

Before updating, verify these are backed up (they won't be touched, but safety first):

```bash
# Check your backup is recent
ls -la /tmp/alex-prime-backups/

# Or run a fresh backup now
/home/ubuntu/.openclaw/workspace/scripts/daily-backup.sh
```

**Safe files (never touched by updates):**
- `~/.openclaw/openclaw.json` â€” Main config
- `~/.openclaw/workspace/` â€” All personality files (SOUL.md, MEMORY.md, etc.)
- `~/.openclaw/credentials/` â€” API keys, WhatsApp session

---

## ðŸš€ Update Methods

### Method 1: One-Line Installer (Recommended)

```bash
curl -fsSL https://openclaw.ai/install.sh | bash -s -- --no-onboard
```

This will:
- Detect existing install
- Upgrade in place
- Run `openclaw doctor` automatically
- Keep all your settings

---

### Method 2: Manual NPM Update

```bash
# Step 1: Check current version
openclaw --version

# Step 2: Update to latest
npm i -g openclaw@latest

# Step 3: Run health check
openclaw doctor

# Step 4: Restart gateway
openclaw gateway restart

# Step 5: Verify health
openclaw health
```

---

### Method 3: Update via OpenClaw Command

```bash
# If installed from source (git)
openclaw update

# This does everything automatically:
# - Fetches latest code
# - Installs dependencies
# - Runs doctor
# - Restarts gateway
```

---

## ðŸ”§ Post-Update Verification

After any update, run these checks:

```bash
# 1. Check new version
openclaw --version

# 2. Check gateway status
openclaw gateway status

# 3. Check system health
openclaw health

# 4. Check logs for errors
openclaw logs --follow
# (Press Ctrl+C to exit logs)
```

---

## ðŸ”„ Switching Update Channels

```bash
# Switch to beta (newer features, less stable)
openclaw update --channel beta

# Switch to dev (bleeding edge)
openclaw update --channel dev

# Switch back to stable
openclaw update --channel stable
```

---

## âª Rollback (If Something Breaks)

### Rollback to specific version:
```bash
# Install known-good version
npm i -g openclaw@2026.1.29

# Restart
openclaw gateway restart

# Run doctor
openclaw doctor
```

### Check available versions:
```bash
npm view openclaw versions --json | tail -20
```

---

## ðŸ” What's Preserved During Updates

| Component | Location | Preserved? |
|-----------|----------|------------|
| Main config | `~/.openclaw/openclaw.json` | âœ… YES |
| Personality | `~/.openclaw/workspace/` | âœ… YES |
| Credentials | `~/.openclaw/credentials/` | âœ… YES |
| WhatsApp session | `~/.openclaw/credentials/whatsapp/` | âœ… YES |
| Memory database | `~/.openclaw/memory/` | âœ… YES |
| Agent sessions | `~/.openclaw/agents/` | âœ… YES |

---

## ðŸ“ž Troubleshooting

### Gateway won't start after update:
```bash
openclaw doctor
openclaw gateway restart
```

### Config issues:
```bash
# View current config
openclaw gateway config.get

# Reset to defaults (careful!)
openclaw doctor --repair
```

### Check for errors:
```bash
openclaw logs --follow
```

---

## ðŸ“… Update Schedule Recommendation

- **Stable releases**: Update monthly
- **Security patches**: Update immediately
- **Major versions**: Test on non-critical system first

---

*For support: https://discord.gg/clawd*
*Docs: https://docs.openclaw.ai*

files.name: REMOTION-SKILLS-GUIDE.md
files.content:
# Remotion Skills Guide â€” Programmatic Video Creation

## What is Remotion?

**Remotion** = React + Video. You write TypeScript/React code â†’ export MP4 videos.

- **Creator:** Jonny Burger (Twitter: @JnyBgr)
- **License:** Free for individuals/small teams (3 people)
- **Pricing:** $25/mo per seat (creators) OR $0.01/render + $100/mo min (automation)
- **Output:** Real MP4 files, not screen recordings

---

## Why Remotion for Pulse Graphix?

| Problem | Old Way | Remotion Way |
|---------|---------|--------------|
| 10 TikToks/week | 5 hours editing | 10 minutes generating |
| Consistent branding | Templates in Canva | Code-based templates |
| A/B testing thumbnails | Manual creation | Change one variable, re-render |
| Multi-language content | Re-edit manually | Change text prop, re-render 10 languages |
| Data-driven videos | Impossible | Feed API data â†’ generate 100 videos |

---

## Core Concepts

### 1. Frames
Videos are 30-60fps. Frame 0 = start, Frame 900 = 15 seconds at 60fps.

### 2. Interpolation
Smooth transitions using `interpolate()`:
```typescript
const opacity = interpolate(frame, [0, 30], [0, 1]); // Fade in over 1 sec
```

### 3. Spring Animation
Physics-based animations:
```typescript
const scale = spring({frame, fps, config: {damping: 12}});
```

### 4. Sequences
Time-based content organization:
```typescript
<Sequence from={0} durationInFrames={60}> // Frames 0-60
  <Intro />
</Sequence>
<Sequence from={60} durationInFrames={90}> // Frames 60-150
  <MainContent />
</Sequence>
```

---

## Template Library (For Your Use)

### Template 1: "3 Tips" Video
**Platform:** TikTok/Reels (1080Ã—1920, 12-15 sec)
**Use case:** Quick tips, listicles, "X things you need to know"
**Code location:** `remotion-templates/VideoTemplate.tsx`

**How to customize:**
```typescript
const TIPS = [
  {emoji: 'ðŸ¢', text: 'Slow load times', color: '#E74C3C'},
  {emoji: 'ðŸ“±', text: 'Bad mobile UX', color: '#3498DB'},
  {emoji: 'ðŸ”˜', text: 'No clear CTA', color: '#27AE60'},
];
// Change this array â†’ new video in seconds
```

### Template 2: "Quote Card" Video
**Platform:** All platforms
**Use case:** Motivational content, testimonials
**Animation:** Text reveal line-by-line

### Template 3: "Before/After"
**Platform:** LinkedIn, Instagram
**Use case:** Portfolio showcase
**Animation:** Slider reveal

### Template 4: "Number Counter"
**Platform:** LinkedIn
**Use case:** Stats, results, case studies
**Animation:** Numbers count up

### Template 5: "Day in Life"
**Platform:** TikTok/Reels
**Use case:** Behind the scenes, personal brand
**Animation:** Photo slideshow + text overlays

---

## CLI Commands

```bash
# Start development server (preview in browser)
npx remotion studio src/index.ts

# Render video to MP4
npx remotion render src/index.ts VideoTemplate out/video.mp4

# Render specific composition
npx remotion render src/index.ts MyVideo out.mp4 --props='{"title":"Hello"}'

# Render still frame
npx remotion still src/index.ts TitleCard title.png
```

---

## Integration with Your Workflow

### Plan A: Local Development (Start here)
1. Design templates in code
2. Preview in browser
3. Generate videos manually
4. Upload to social platforms

### Plan B: n8n Automation (Scale up)
```
Google Sheet (content) 
  â†’ n8n trigger
    â†’ Remotion render API call
      â†’ Save to Google Drive
        â†’ Buffer/Post to Social
```

### Plan C: Remotion Cloud (Enterprise)
- Use Remotion's Lambda for serverless rendering
- No local setup needed
- Pay per render ($0.01/sec)

---

## Pricing Breakdown

| Plan | Cost | Best For |
|------|------|----------|
| **Free** | $0 | Individuals, testing |
| **Creator** | $25/mo/seat | You making videos for yourself |
| **Automator** | $0.01/render + $100/mo | Building tools for clients |
| **Enterprise** | $500+/mo | Custom contracts |

**Your use case:** Start with Free â†’ Creator ($25/mo) â†’ Automator if building Pulse Graphix video tool

---

## Sample Commands for Your Workflow

```bash
# Generate 10 quote videos from CSV
cat quotes.csv | xargs -I {} npx remotion render src/index.ts QuoteCard "out/{}.mp4" --props="{\"quote\":\"{}\"}"

# Batch render for the week
for tip in tips/*.json; do
  npx remotion render src/index.ts TipsVideo "out/$(basename $tip .json).mp4" --props="$(cat $tip)"
done
```

---

## Resources

- **Docs:** https://www.remotion.dev/docs
- **Examples:** https://github.com/remotion-dev/remotion/tree/main/packages/example
- **Discord:** https://discord.gg/remotion
- **GitHub:** https://github.com/remotion-dev/remotion

---

*Created: February 25, 2026*
*Status: Remotion installed, first template created*
*Next: Build remaining templates, connect to n8n automation*

files.content:
# Search API Alternatives Research
*For Kabundji â€” February 14, 2026*

## Current Situation
- **Brave Search API**: Free tier = 1 request/second, 2,000 queries/month
- **Status**: Rate limited (hit quota)
- **Need**: Alternative search APIs for prospect research

---

## RECOMMENDED: Google Programmable Search API â­

### Free Tier
- **100 queries/day** (3,000/month)
- **$5 per 1,000 queries** after free tier
- **Hard cap**: 10,000 queries/day ($50/day max)

### Pros
- âœ… Google index (largest)
- âœ… JSON API, easy integration
- âœ… Custom search engine setup
- âœ… Region/language filtering
- âœ… Image search available

### Cons
- âŒ Not real Google results (simplified, no knowledge graphs)
- âŒ Smaller result set than real Google
- âŒ May differ from actual Google rankings

### Setup
1. Create Google Cloud account
2. Enable Custom Search JSON API
3. Create Programmable Search Engine
4. Get API key + CX (search engine ID)

### Best For
- Local business prospecting
- General web search automation
- SEO ranking checks

---

## OPTION 2: Bing Search API (Retiring Soon âš ï¸)

### Pricing
- **Free**: 1,000 transactions/month
- **Paid**: $15-25 per 1,000 searches

### âš ï¸ CRITICAL: Bing retiring API on August 11, 2025
- Microsoft replacing with "Grounding with Bing Search"
- Only works within Azure AI Foundry
- NOT recommended for new projects

---

## OPTION 3: SerpApi (Paid, Best for Real Results)

### Pricing
- **Developer**: $50/month = 5,000 searches
- **$2 per 1,000** at scale (1M+ searches)
- Can do 100M+ searches/month

### Pros
- âœ… Real Google/Bing/Yahoo/Yandex/DuckDuckGo results
- âœ… All search engines (Google, Bing, Yandex, Baidu, etc.)
- âœ… No rate limits like official APIs
- âœ… Knowledge graphs, carousels, all result types
- âœ… Good for SEO tracking

### Cons
- âŒ $50/month minimum
- âŒ Web scraping approach (may break if engines change)

### Best For
- High-volume prospecting
- SEO monitoring
- Real Google results needed

---

## OPTION 4: Tavily AI Search API

### Pricing
- **Free**: 1,000 API calls/month
- **Paid**: Starts at ~$0.01 per search

### Pros
- âœ… AI-optimized results
- âœ… Summarized content
- âœ… Good for research tasks

### Cons
- âŒ Smaller index than Google
- âŒ French locale coverage unknown

---

## OPTION 5: Exa (formerly Metaphor)

### Pricing
- **Free**: 100 searches/month
- **Paid**: $0.015 per search

### Pros
- âœ… Semantic/expert search
- âœ… Good for finding authoritative sources

### Cons
- âŒ Smaller index
- âŒ Expensive for high volume

---

## COMPARISON TABLE

| Provider | Free Tier | Paid Tier | Real Google? | French Results | Best Use |
|----------|-----------|-----------|--------------|----------------|----------|
| **Brave** (current) | 2,000/mo | $3/1K | No (own index) | âœ… Good | Privacy-focused |
| **Google Custom** â­ | 3,000/mo | $5/1K | Partial | âœ… Excellent | Best replacement |
| **SerpApi** | None | $2-10/1K | âœ… Yes | âœ… Yes | High volume/SEO |
| **Tavily** | 1,000/mo | ~$0.01/search | AI summarizer | ? | AI research |
| **Exa** | 100/mo | $0.015/search | No (semantic) | ? | Expert search |

---

## RECOMMENDATION

### Immediate Action
1. **Sign up for Google Programmable Search API**
   - 100 free searches/day = enough for prospect research
   - Easy to integrate ($5/1K after free tier)
   - URL: https://programmablesearchengine.google.com/about/

### Long Term
2. **Consider SerpApi** if volume > 5,000/month
   - $50/month for real Google results
   - No rate limits
   - Best for serious prospecting automation

---

## INTEGRATION NOTES

### OpenClaw Config
Currently using `brave` provider. Can switch to:
- `google` (Custom Search API)
- Or use direct HTTP calls to other services

### Contact
Need help with API integration? I can write the config once you have keys.

---

*Research completed: 2026-02-14*  
*Use this for planning which APIs to subscribe to*

files.name: SECURITY_AUDIT_2026-02-13.md
files.content:
# OpenClaw Security Audit Report
**Date:** 2026-02-13  
**System:** Ubuntu 24.04.3 LTS (AWS EC2)  
**User:** ubuntu (non-root)  
**Audit By:** Alex Prime

---

## ðŸš¨ CRITICAL Finding: Firewall Disabled

**Status:** **INSECURE - IMMEDIATE ACTION REQUIRED**

Ubuntu UFW firewall is **INACTIVE**. Your VPS is exposed on all ports.

```
Status: inactive
```

**Risk:** Any service listening is accessible from the internet without filtering.

**Fix Required:**
```bash
# Enable UFW with safe defaults
sudo ufw default deny incoming
sudo ufw default allow outgoing
sudo ufw allow 22/tcp    # SSH (required for access)
sudo ufw allow 443/tcp   # HTTPS (if using)
sudo ufw allow 80/tcp    # HTTP (if using)
sudo ufw enable

# Verify
sudo ufw status verbose
```

---

## ðŸ”‘ Credentials Security Assessment

### âœ… Good: File Permissions

| File/Directory | Permission | Status |
|----------------|------------|--------|
| `~/.openclaw/credentials/` | 700 (drwx------) | âœ… Secure |
| `~/.openclaw/openclaw.json` | 600 (-rw-------) | âœ… Secure |
| `github_token.txt` | 600 | âœ… Secure |
| `vercel_token.txt` | 600 | âœ… Secure |
| `n8n.json` | 600 | âœ… Secure |
| `google_client_secret.json` | 600 | âœ… Secure |
| `~/.ssh/` | 700 | âœ… Secure |
| `~/.ssh/authorized_keys` | 600 | âœ… Secure |

### âš ï¸ API Keys Stored In Plain Text

**Location:** `~/.openclaw/openclaw.json`

API keys are stored in this file with proper permissions (600), but they are:
- Visible to the ubuntu user
- In JSON format (human readable)
- Not encrypted at rest

**Keys Found:**
- OpenRouter API key
- Other model provider keys

**Mitigation:** File permissions prevent other users from reading. This is the expected OpenClaw behavior.

---

## ðŸŒ Network Exposure

### Open Ports (Active Listening)

| Port | Protocol | Bind Address | Service | Risk |
|------|----------|--------------|---------|------|
| 22 | TCP | 0.0.0.0 (all) | SSH | âš ï¸ Needs firewall |
| 53 | UDP/TCP | 127.0.0.53 | System DNS | âœ… Local only |
| 323 | UDP | 127.0.0.1 | NTP | âœ… Local only |
| 5353 | UDP | 0.0.0.0 / [::] | mDNS (OpenClaw) | âš ï¸ Multicast only |
| 18789 | TCP | 127.0.0.1 | OpenClaw Gateway | âœ… Local only |
| 18792 | TCP | 127.0.0.1 | OpenClaw Gateway | âœ… Local only |
| 44573 | UDP | 0.0.0.0 | Ephemeral | Low risk |

**Good News:**
- OpenClaw gateway only listens on localhost (127.0.0.1)
- Cannot be accessed from external network directly

---

## ðŸ”’ SSH Security

### âœ… Key-Based Authentication
- `~/.ssh/authorized_keys` exists
- Proper permissions (600)
- SSH directory proper permissions (700)

### âš ï¸ Unknown Configuration
Could not read `/etc/ssh/sshd_config` (requires sudo)

**Recommended Checks:**
```bash
sudo grep -E "^(PermitRootLogin|PasswordAuthentication|PubkeyAuthentication)" /etc/ssh/sshd_config
```

**Best Practices:**
- `PermitRootLogin no` (disable root login)
- `PasswordAuthentication no` (keys only)
- `PubkeyAuthentication yes` (ensure enabled)

---

## ðŸ›¡ï¸ OpenClaw Security Configuration

### OpenClaw Config File
**Location:** `~/.openclaw/openclaw.json`
- Version: 2026.2.6-3
- Permissions: 600 (good)

### Security Features Available
Run these commands to audit and fix:
```bash
# OpenClaw security audit
openclaw security audit --deep

# Apply safe defaults (prompts before changes)
openclaw security audit --fix
```

---

## ðŸ“œ Prompt Injection Risks

### Current State
- System prompt includes safety guidelines
- OpenClaw uses instruction hierarchies
- Model-level safety filters active

### Additional Recommendations
1. **Disable tool auto-execution** for critical operations
2. **Add confirmation prompts** before:
   - Sending messages
   - Executing shell commands
   - Accessing credentials
3. **Log all external actions** for review

---

## ðŸ”§ Remediation Plan

### Priority 1: Enable Firewall (CRITICAL)
```bash
sudo ufw default deny incoming
sudo ufw default allow outgoing
sudo ufw allow 22/tcp
sudo ufw enable
sudo ufw status
```

### Priority 2: Harden SSH
```bash
# Run as root or sudo
sudo sed -i 's/^#*PermitRootLogin.*/PermitRootLogin no/' /etc/ssh/sshd_config
sudo sed -i 's/^#*PasswordAuthentication.*/PasswordAuthentication no/' /etc/ssh/sshd_config
sudo systemctl restart sshd
```

### Priority 3: Enable Automatic Security Updates
```bash
sudo apt install unattended-upgrades
sudo dpkg-reconfigure unattended-upgrades
# Select "Yes" for automatic updates
```

### Priority 4: OpenClaw Security Hardening
```bash
# Run OpenClaw security audit
openclaw security audit --deep

# Review and apply fixes
openclaw security audit --fix
```

### Priority 5: Verify Credentials Security
```bash
# Check all credential files have 600 permissions
ls -la ~/.openclaw/credentials/
ls -la ~/.openclaw/openclaw.json
ls -la ~/.ssh/

# Fix if needed:
chmod 700 ~/.openclaw/credentials/
chmod 600 ~/.openclaw/credentials/*
chmod 600 ~/.openclaw/openclaw.json
chmod 700 ~/.ssh/
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/authorized_keys
```

---

## ðŸ“Š Security Score

| Category | Score | Notes |
|----------|-------|-------|
| Firewall | ðŸ”´ 0/10 | Disabled - CRITICAL |
| SSH | ðŸŸ¡ 6/10 | Key auth, unknown config |
| Credentials | ðŸŸ¢ 8/10 | Good permissions, plain text |
| OpenClaw | ðŸŸ¢ 7/10 | Localhost only, needs audit |
| Updates | ðŸŸ¡ 5/10 | Unknown auto-update status |
| **Overall** | ðŸŸ¡ **5.2/10** | **Fix firewall ASAP** |

---

## ðŸ“‹ Status Check Commands

Run these anytime to verify security:

```bash
# Check firewall
sudo ufw status verbose

# Check open ports
ss -ltnup

# Check OpenClaw security
openclaw security audit --deep

# Check file permissions
ls -la ~/.openclaw/credentials/
ls -la ~/.ssh/

# Check SSH config
sudo grep -E "^(PermitRootLogin|PasswordAuthentication)" /etc/ssh/sshd_config
```

---

## ðŸ”„ Schedule Periodic Audits

Recommend weekly security checks:
```bash
# Add to crontab (run Sundays at 2am)
0 2 * * 0 /usr/local/bin/openclaw security audit --deep >> ~/.openclaw/security-audit.log 2>&1
```

---

## Next Actions Required

1. **Approve firewall enablement?** (Y/N)
2. **Approve SSH hardening?** (Y/N)
3. **Run OpenClaw security audit --fix?** (Y/N)
4. **Schedule weekly security audits?** (Y/N)

---

*Document stored in: `docs/SECURITY_AUDIT_2026-02-13.md`*  
*Last updated: 2026-02-13 16:05 UTC*

# Subagent Pyramid Architecture
*Proposed Multi-Agent System for Pulse Graphix*  
*Design: 2026-02-14 | Status: Draft for Review*

---

## Overview

**Goal:** Scale Alex Prime's capabilities by delegating to specialized subagents  
**Structure:** 1 Executive (Alex Prime) â†’ 4 Managers â†’ 15+ Specialists

```
                    â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
                    â”‚  Alex Prime â”‚
                    â”‚  (You)      â”‚
                    â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
                           â”‚
           â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”

        â”‚BD  â”‚ â”‚OPS â”‚ â”‚DEV â”‚ â”‚MKT â”‚

          â”‚      â”‚      â”‚      â”‚
       3-4    3-4    3-4    3-4
     Agents  Agents  Agents  Agents
```

---

## Manager Agents (4)

### 1. BD Manager â€” "Kai"
**Focus:** Business Development, Prospecting, Sales

**Reports to:** Alex Prime  
**Manages:**

- Outreach Agent â€” Cold calling, email sequences
- Proposal Agent â€” Quote generation, presentations
- Closer Agent â€” Negotiation, contract signing

**KPIs:**
- Leads generated per week
- Conversion rate (lead â†’ meeting â†’ client)
- Revenue per quarter

**Skills Required:**
- `web_search` â€” Find prospects
- `web_fetch` â€” Research companies
- `message` â€” Send outreach
- `sessions_spawn` â€” Delegate research tasks

---

### 2. Ops Manager â€” "Aria"
**Focus:** Operations, Admin, Client Management

**Reports to:** Alex Prime  
**Manages:**
- Project Agent â€” Timeline tracking, deliverables
- Finance Agent â€” Invoicing, payments, reporting
- Support Agent â€” Client communication, tickets
- CRM Agent â€” Data entry, follow-ups

**KPIs:**
- On-time delivery rate
- Client satisfaction score
- Invoice-to-payment time

**Skills Required:**
- `gog` â€” Calendar, email
- `cron` â€” Scheduled tasks
- `n8n` â€” Workflow automation
- `memory_search` â€” Context retrieval

---

### 3. Dev Manager â€” "Zen"
**Focus:** Development, Templates, Technical Output

**Reports to:** Alex Prime  
**Manages:**
- Frontend Agent â€” HTML, CSS, React components
- Framer Agent â€” Template building, marketplace
- Automation Agent â€” n8n workflows, scripts
- QA Agent â€” Testing, validation

**KPIs:**
- Templates shipped per month
- Code quality score
- Client project delivery time

**Skills Required:**
- `write`/`edit` â€” Code generation
- `exec` â€” Testing, deployment
- `browser` â€” Visual QA
- `canvas` â€” Asset generation

---

### 4. Marketing Manager â€” "Nova"
**Focus:** Content, Social, Brand

**Reports to:** Alex Prime  
**Manages:**
- Content Agent â€” Blog posts, case studies
- Social Agent â€” LinkedIn, Twitter posts
- Design Agent â€” Graphics, thumbnails
- Video Agent â€” Scripts, editing guidance

**KPIs:**
- Content pieces per week
- Engagement rate
- Lead attribution from content

**Skills Required:**
- `web_search` â€” Topic research
- `image` â€” Thumbnail/design generation
- `tts` â€” Voice content
- `message` â€” Social posting

---

## Specialist Agents (15)

| Manager | Specialist | Role | Key Tools |
|---------|-----------|------|-----------|
| **Kai (BD)** | Research Agent | Lead discovery | web_search, web_fetch |
| | Outreach Agent | Cold outreach | message, memory |
| | Proposal Agent | Quotes/proposals | write, canvas |
| | Closer Agent | Negotiation | message, sessions_send |
| **Aria (Ops)** | Project Agent | Timeline tracking | cron, gog, memory |
| | Finance Agent | Invoicing | write, gog |
| | Support Agent | Client comms | message, sessions_send |
| | CRM Agent | Data management | n8n, memory |
| **Zen (Dev)** | Frontend Agent | HTML/CSS/React | write, edit, browser |
| | Framer Agent | Template builder | browser, exec |
| | Automation Agent | n8n/scripts | write, exec |
| | QA Agent | Testing | browser, exec |
| **Nova (Mkt)** | Content Agent | Writing | write, web_search |
| | Social Agent | Posting | message |
| | Design Agent | Graphics | canvas, image |

---

## Communication Flow

```
Kabundji â†’ Alex Prime (Executive)
                â”‚
                â”œâ”€â†’ Kai (BD) â†’ [Research, Outreach, Proposal, Closer]
                â”œâ”€â†’ Aria (Ops) â†’ [Project, Finance, Support, CRM]
                â”œâ”€â†’ Zen (Dev) â†’ [Frontend, Framer, Automation, QA]
                â””â”€â†’ Nova (Mkt) â†’ [Content, Social, Design, Video]
```

**Protocol:**
1. Specialists report to Managers
2. Managers report to Alex Prime
3. Alex Prime reports to Kabundji
4. Emergency escalations skip levels

---

## Implementation Phases

### Phase 1: Foundation (Week 1-2)
- [ ] Create 4 Manager agent definitions
- [ ] Set up session spawning templates
- [ ] Define handoff protocols
- [ ] Test with simple task delegation

### Phase 2: Core Team (Week 3-4)
- [ ] Deploy Kai (BD) + Research Agent
- [ ] Deploy Zen (Dev) + Frontend Agent
- [ ] Set up reporting dashboards
- [ ] Refine communication patterns

### Phase 3: Full Pyramid (Month 2)
- [ ] Add remaining Specialists
- [ ] Automate manager-to-manager handoffs
- [ ] Build overview dashboard
- [ ] Optimize based on usage patterns

### Phase 4: Autonomy (Month 3+)
- [ ] Managers self-delegate to Specialists
- [ ] Alex Prime only escalations + strategic
- [ ] Weekly all-hands summary reports

---

## Cost Projection

| Resource | Estimate | Notes |
|----------|----------|-------|
| Sessions/month | ~500 | 4 managers Ã— daily + specialists |
| Avg session cost | $0.05 | Quick tasks, cached context |
| Monthly cost | ~$25 | Negligible vs value generated |
| Setup time | 20 hours | One-time investment |

---

## Technical Setup

### Session Spawning Pattern
```javascript
// Example: Delegate research task to Kai's Research Agent
sessions_spawn({
  agentId: "kai-research-agent",
  task: "Find 10 boulangerie prospects in Torcy without websites",
  label: "prospect-research-001",
  timeout: 300
})
```

### Communication Template
```
[FROM: Kai (BD Manager)]
[TO: Alex Prime]
[TYPE: Daily Report]

âœ… Completed: 5 prospects researched
ðŸ” Found: C.C.P Fournil, Le BelvÃ©dÃ¨re, Pho Quynh...
ðŸ“Š Conversion: 4 qualified, 1 low priority
â° Next: Outreach tomorrow 14h

[Attach: prospects/daily-YYYY-MM-DD.md]
```

---

## ACTION REQUIRED

**For Kabundji Review:**
1. [ ] Approve architecture design
2. [ ] Prioritize which managers to deploy first
3. [ ] Decide: Build all at once or phased?
4. [ ] Resource allocation approval

---

*Document: `docs/SUBAGENT-PYRAMID-ARCHITECTURE.md`*  
*Next Step: Deploy Kai (BD Manager) + Research Agent as MVP*

# HEARTBEAT.md

## âš ï¸ CRITICAL: DO ACTUAL WORK, NOT JUST ACK!
Kabundji's directive: "You haven't been productive" â€” use heartbeat time for REAL work.

## On Each Heartbeat (every 10 min):

### 1. Update Dashboard Status (MANDATORY!)
Run the data sync script to generate fresh status.json + data.json from workspace, then push:
```bash
cd /home/ubuntu/.openclaw/workspace
VERCEL_TOKEN=$(cat credentials/vercel_token.txt)
# Alex Prime dashboard
node scripts/generate-dashboard-data.js
cd dashboard && git add -A && git commit -m "Heartbeat $(date +%H:%M)" && git push origin main && vercel --prod --yes --token "$VERCEL_TOKEN"
# Pulse Graphix dashboard
cd /home/ubuntu/.openclaw/workspace
node scripts/generate-pulse-graphix-data.js
cd pulse-graphix-dashboard && git add -A && git commit -m "Heartbeat $(date +%H:%M)" && git push origin main && vercel --prod --yes --force --token "$VERCEL_TOKEN"
```

Dashboard URL: https://dashboard-ten-mu-52.vercel.app

Fields to update:
- `lastUpdate` â€” current timestamp
- `lastHeartbeat` â€” current timestamp  
- `status` â€” active/working/idle
- `currentTask` â€” what you're doing RIGHT NOW
- `recentActions` â€” last 5 things you did
- `pendingTasks` â€” what's next
- `completedTasks` â€” what's done

### 2. CHECK FOR PENDING WORK (ALWAYS)
Read `TODO.md` â€” if there's unfinished work, **DO IT NOW**. Don't wait for instructions.

### 3. Quick Checks (rotate through these)
- [ ] Unread urgent emails (gog CLI)
- [ ] Calendar events in next 2 hours
- [ ] Any new messages to respond to

### 4. PRODUCTIVE ACTIONS (pick at least one if nothing urgent)
- Continue unfinished tasks from TODO.md
- Build/improve templates or tools
- Create marketing drafts
- Research leads
- Organize files
- Commit and push changes

### 5. Log Activity
Append note to `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md` if something notable happened.

---

## ðŸš¨ RULES FOR HEARTBEAT RESPONSES:
- **If there's pending work** â†’ DO THE WORK, don't say HEARTBEAT_OK
- **If you completed something** â†’ Report what you did
- **Only reply HEARTBEAT_OK** if you genuinely checked everything AND there's nothing to do

*"I want to wake up every morning and be like, 'Wow, you got a lot done while I was sleeping.'"* â€” Kabundji

# Week 1 Content Plan â€” Pulse Graphix
## 15 Posts Across 5 Platforms (Feb 26 - Mar 4)

---

## LINKEDIN (5 posts)

### Post 1: Thought Leadership (Monday)
**Hook:** "95% of business websites are leaking money."

**Body:**
Here's what 20 years in tech has taught me:

Your website isn't a brochure.
It's a 24/7 salesperson.

Yet most businesses treat it like an expense instead of an investment.

3 signs your website is costing you customers:

1ï¸âƒ£ Loads slower than 3 seconds = 53% of mobile visitors bounce
2ï¸âƒ£ No clear CTA = visitors don't know what to do
3ï¸âƒ£ No social proof = visitors don't trust you

Fix these 3 things and watch your inquiry rate climb.

Or keep wondering why competitors book more calls.

Your move.

**Hashtags:** #WebDesign #SmallBusiness #DigitalMarketing #Entrepreneurship

---

### Post 2: Portfolio Showcase (Wednesday)
**Visual:** Before/after website mockup

**Body:**
Before: Generic template, blurry images, broken mobile layout
After: Clean custom design, optimized photos, perfect mobile experience

**Result:** Client went from 2 inquiries/month to 12.

Lesson: Design isn't decoration. Design is revenue.

Swipe for the full transformation â†’

[Link to case study]

**Hashtags:** #WebDesign #BeforeAfter #CaseStudy #DesignThinking

---

### Post 3: Checklist (Friday)
**Hook:** "Website Audit Checklist: Does yours pass?"

**Body:**
Your website has 10 seconds to convince visitors.

Here's your 10-point survival checklist:

â˜‘ï¸ Loads under 3 seconds
â˜‘ï¸ Mobile-first design
â˜‘ï¸ Clear headline (what you do)
â˜‘ï¸ Visible contact info
â˜‘ï¸ Pricing or "starting at"
â˜‘ï¸ Portfolio/examples
â˜‘ï¸ Testimonials/reviews
â˜‘ï¸ Social media links
â˜‘ï¸ Booking form/button
â˜‘ï¸ SSL certificate (https)

How many did you check?

1-3: ðŸš¨ Critical
4-6: âš ï¸ Needs work
7-10: âœ… Strong

Comment your score ðŸ‘‡

**Hashtags:** #WebsiteTips #SmallBusiness #DigitalPresence

---

### Post 4: Personal Story (Sunday)
**Hook:** "I almost quit after my first client."

**Body:**
2004. First freelance gig.

Client wanted a website. Simple enough.

3 weeks of work. Countless revisions. Sleepless nights.

Delivery day: "This isn't what I wanted." Refused payment.

I was devastated. Questioning everything.

Then my mentor said something that changed everything:

"You didn't fail. You learned what questions to ask next time."

I went back. Asked better questions. Understood the vision.

Redesigned it. Client paid. Referred 3 friends.

20 years later: lesson still applies.

The client isn't the enemy. Clarity is the solution.

**Hashtags:** #FreelanceLife #Entrepreneurship #DesignThinking

---

### Post 5: Poll (Tuesday)
**Question:** What's your biggest website challenge?

**Options:**
A) Getting traffic to the site
B) Converting visitors to customers
C) Mobile optimization
D) Don't have a website yet

**Follow-up:** Will comment with solutions based on top response.

**Hashtags:** #Poll #WebDesign #SmallBusiness

---

## INSTAGRAM STORIES (5 stories daily = 35, here are highlights)

### Story 1: Behind the Scenes
**Visual:** Screenshot of design tools, workspace
**Text:** "Designing websites in Paris at 7 AM. Coffee â˜• code ðŸ’» repeat."
**Sticker:** Location Paris

### Story 2: Quick Tip
**Visual:** Canva-made graphic with tip
**Text:** "ðŸš€ Quick Win: Add your phone number to your website header. 47% more calls."
**CTA:** "Swipe up for more tips"

### Story 3: Before/After Reveal
**Visual:** Split screen comparison
**Text:** "Client transformation ðŸŽ¯"
**Interactive:** Poll sticker â€” "Which grabs you? Left or Right?"

### Story 4: Question Sticker
**Visual:** Typing on keyboard
**Text:** "Working on something new. What website feature do you wish you had?"
**Interactive:** Question sticker responses

### Story 5: Testimonial
**Visual:** Quote card design
**Text:** "3x more bookings in 2 months" â€” Sarah, Bakery Owner
**CTA:** "DM 'WEBSITE' for details"

---

## TIKTOK/REELS (3 videos)

### Video 1: "3 Website Mistakes Costing You Money"
**Hook:** (0-3 sec) Point at camera: "Your website is losing customers. Here's why."
**Content:**
- Mistake #1: No clear CTA
- Mistake #2: Slow loading
- Mistake #3: Bad mobile design
**CTA:** "Follow for more web tips"
**Music:** Trending chime/success sound

### Video 2: "POV: Before vs After Website Redesign"
**Visual:** Side-by-side scroll through both sites
**Hook:** "POV: You finally invested in a proper website"
**Text overlays:**
- BEFORE: "Templated. Generic. Ignored."
- AFTER: "Custom. Bold. Booked out."
**CTA:** "Which would you choose?"

### Video 3: "Day in the Life: Web Designer/Founder"
**Content:** Morning routine â†’ client call â†’ design work â†’ coffee break â†’ evening review
**Behind the scenes:** Real workspace, real process
**Trending audio:** Popular motivational/inspirational track
**Text:** "Building digital dreams in Paris ðŸ‡«ðŸ‡·"

---

## FACEBOOK (2 posts)

### Post 1: Educational (Thursday)
**Headline:** "Why Your Website Isn't Converting (And How to Fix It)"

**Body:**
You've spent money on ads. You have traffic.
But the phone isn't ringing.

Here's the uncomfortable truth: your website is the problem.

5 conversion killers:

1. Confusing navigation â€” Visitors can't find what they need
2. No clear value proposition â€” They don't know why to choose you
3. Weak calls-to-action â€” "Contact us" isn't compelling
4. Missing trust signals â€” No reviews, testimonials, or proof
5. Poor mobile experience â€” 60%+ of your traffic is mobile

The fix? Audit your site against these 5 points. Be brutal.

Your website should work harder than you do.

**Hashtags:** #WebDesignTips #SmallBusinessGrowth #DigitalMarketing

### Post 2: Engagement (Saturday)
**Question:** "What made you choose your current website platform? WordPress? Wix? Squarespace? Something else?"

**Follow-up strategy:** Comments asking about their experience â†’ DM with tailored advice â†’ soft pitch for Pulse Graphix services

| **Pulse Architects** | `email-sequence-pulse-architects.html` | Architects needing portfolio + revenue | Portfolio demo + revenue calculator |

---

## ðŸ“… Email Sequence Structure

### Email 1 â€” Introduction (Day 0)
- **Goal:** Get attention, establish credibility
- **Content:** Problem observation + solution preview + soft CTA
- **Tone:** Helpful, observant, not salesy

### Email 2 â€” Value/Proof (Day 3-5)
- **Goal:** Build trust, show results
- **Content:** Case study/story + specific numbers + free resource
- **Tone:** Informative, social proof-focused

### Email 3 â€” Final CTA (Day 7-14)
- **Goal:** Get commitment or permission to stay in touch
- **Content:** Two clear options + graceful exit + newsletter offer
- **Tone:** Respectful, professional, non-pushy

---

## ðŸŽ¨ Design Features

- **Dark theme:** Matches current UI aesthetic
- **Brand colors:** Each company has its signature palette
- **Responsive:** Works on mobile and desktop
- **Template variables:** `{{first_name}}`, `{{business_name}}`, etc.
- **Unsubscribe:** GDPR-compliant footer on every email

---

## âš™ï¸ How to Use

1. **Review** the HTML files in-browser (open in Chrome/Firefox)
2. **Customize** the template variables at the top:
   - Replace `{{first_name}}` with actual first name
   - Replace `{{calendar_link}}` with your Calendly/Cal.com URL
   - Replace case study details with real examples
3. **Extract** the HTML for your email platform (remove the preview wrapper)
4. **Test** send to yourself before live deployment
5. **Automate** via n8n, Mailchimp, or similar (set delays between emails)

---

## ðŸ”„ Integration Options

| Platform | How to integrate |
|----------|-----------------|
| **n8n** | HTML node + delay node + Gmail/SendGrid node |
| **Mailchimp** | Import HTML as template, set automation workflow |
| **Brevo** | Create campaign, paste HTML, set trigger rules |
| **HubSpot** | Email template + workflow automation |

---

## ðŸ“ Next Steps (Pending Kabundji Approval)

- [ ] Review tone and messaging
- [ ] Add real case studies (currently placeholders)
- [ ] Replace `{{calendar_link}}` with actual Calendly URLs
- [ ] Set up email automation in n8n or chosen platform
- [ ] Test send sequences to yourself first
- [ ] Launch to prospect lists

---

## ðŸ’¡ Optional Enhancements

- Add A/B test variants (different subject lines)
- Create plain-text fallback versions
- Add tracking pixel for open/click rates
- Segment by industry (different sequences per sector)
- Add SMS follow-up for non-openers

---

**Ready for review!** Check each HTML file to see the full email preview with styling. ðŸŽ¯

# LinkedIn Post Drafts - Batch 1 (Feb 18-21, 2026)
*Ready for Kabundji's review and approval*

---

## Post 1: Thought Leadership - AI Transformation
**Type:** Perspective/Opinion | **Hook:** Strong opening statement | **CTA:** Comment your experience

### Draft:

"AI won't replace designers. But designers who use AI will replace those who don't.

I've seen the divide forming in real-time:

â†’ 6 months ago: "AI art is a trend"
â†’ Today: Top agencies using AI deliver 3x faster, slash costs by 40%
â†’ 6 months from now: It'll be the baseline expectation

Here's what most get wrong:

âŒ Thinking AI is a replacement (it's a multiplier)
âŒ Using generic outputs (you still need taste + direction)
âŒ Ignoring the craftsmanship that clients actually pay for

What clients want hasn't changed:
- Strategy that understands their business
- Designs that convert, not just look pretty
- Partners who think, not just execute

AI just removed the 80% of repetitive work that's been slowing you down.

The designers winning right now?
They spend 20% less time on production.
They reinvest that time into:
â†’ Better client conversations
â†’ Sharper strategy
â†’ Higher-margin creative work

---

3 questions for my network:

1. Which side of this divide are you building toward?
2. What repetitive tasks are you trying to eliminate?
3. What would you create with 20% more time?

Drop a comment â€” I'm curious where everyone stands on this change.

---

#DesignAgency #AITransformation #BusinessStrategy #CreativeDirection #PulseGraphix"

---

## Post 2: Portfolio Showcase (Carousel Style)
**Type:** Visual showcase | **Hook:** "Swipe through this transformation" | **CTA:** Visit profile

### Draft:

"85% of businesses in our local market have websites that lose customers instead of attracting them.

Swipe through 4 transformations we delivered this quarter ðŸŽ¨

â†’ Slide 1: Before (cluttered, confusing, mobile-unfriendly)
â†’ Slide 2: After (clean hierarchy, clear CTAs, 40% faster load)
â†’ Slide 3: Results (metrics + client testimonial)
â†’ Slide 4: The process (AI-assisted + human craft)

ðŸ“Š Real numbers from a recent project:
- Page load: 4.2s â†’ 1.1s
- Bounce rate: 68% â†’ 34%
- Mobile conversion: +127%

The client almost gave up on their website entirely. They thought "people just don't buy from small businesses online."

Turns out?
People don't buy from confusing websites. Period.

Big or small, the principles are the same:
âœ“ Clear value in 3 seconds
âœ“ Trust signals front-loaded
âœ“ Friction removed at every step

DM "AUDIT" if you'd like me to look at your current site â€” I'll send you 3 quick wins, no pitch.

---

#WebDesign #ConversionOptimization #LocalBusiness #BeforeAfter #PulseGraphix"

---

## Post 3: Value Checklist (High-engagement format)
**Type:** "Save this" content | **Hook:** "Bookmark this" | **CTA:** Follow for more

### Draft:

"ðŸš¨ Graphic design red flags that scream 'amateur':

If your designer does these, get a second opinion before you pay:

âŒ 1. No grid system â€” Everything placed 'by eye'
âŒ 2. 3+ fonts on one page (chaos, not character)
âŒ 3. No hierarchy â€” your eye doesn't know where to go first
âŒ 4. Stock photos that don't match your brand tone
âŒ 5. Center-aligned body text (hard to read long-form)
âŒ 6. Generic color palettes (blue/gray for tech, red for urgency)
âŒ 7. Design without strategy â€” "looks good" isn't the goal

Here's what separates professionals:

âœ… Grid systems that create visual rhythm
âœ… 1-2 fonts max, used with intention
âœ… Clear visual hierarchy (what's most important?)
âœ… Curated imagery that reinforces brand story
âœ… Left-aligned body text for readability
âœ… Colors chosen for psychology, not trends
âœ… Every design decision tied to business outcome

My rule: If you can't explain WHY a design choice was made, it shouldn't be there.

---

ðŸ’¾ Save this for your next project brief.

ðŸ“Œ Bookmark for your next designer screening.

ðŸ”” Follow for weekly design tips (I post these every Tuesday)

---

#DesignTips #Branding101 #HiringDesigners #GraphicDesign #MarketingMaterials #PulseGraphix"

---

## Post 4: Lesson Learned / Behind the Scenes
**Type:** Story/Personal insight | **Hook:** "I used to think..." | **CTA:** Share your story

### Draft:

"I used to say yes to every project.

'Of course I can do that website'
'Logo design? Easy'
'Can you also do the copywriting? Sure'

Then I hit burnout. And my work suffered. And clients were... fine, not thrilled.

The turning point? Saying no.

I turned down 3 projects last month. All paid decent money.

Why?

They weren't a fit. And 'decent money' is expensive if it costs your reputation.

Now I run every opportunity through this filter:

â†’ Is this in my core competency? (Design + AI)
â†’ Does this client understand the value? (not just price)
â†’ Will this work sample attract similar clients I want?
â†’ Can I deliver exceptional results, not just acceptable?

If 4/4 aren't yes â†’ it's a no.

The paradox?
Fewer projects â†’ higher revenue.

Because I can charge premium rates for specialized work.
Because clients get outcomes, not outputs.
Because word spreads when you nail it every time.

Not every project is your project.
Not every client is your client.

And that's okay.

---

What filter do you use for new opportunities?

I'm genuinely curious â€” I learn from how others operate.

---

#FreelanceLife #BusinessLessons #ClientRelationships #DesignBusiness #PulseGraphix #InvestInCongo"

---

## Post 5: Poll / Engagement Starter
**Type:** Poll | **Hook:** "Quick poll" | **CTA:** Vote + explain in comments

### Draft:

"Quick poll for my fellow agency owners and freelancers ðŸŽ¯

You're onboarding a new client. What's your biggest friction point?

A) Getting clear requirements (vague briefs)
B) Pricing conversations (scope creep fear)
C) Setting expectations on timelines
D) The actual design work (rarely the problem ðŸ˜‰)

Bonus question in comments:
â†’ How do YOU solve this? Drop your process â€” let's crowdsource best practices.

---

My answer: It's 100% 'A' for me.

I solved it with a mandatory discovery call + standardized brief template.

Takes 30 minutes. Saves 10 hours of revisions.

Your turn ðŸ‘‡

---

#AgencyLife #ClientOnboarding #FreelanceTips #DesignBusiness #PulseGraphix"

---

## ðŸ“‹ Scheduling Recommendations

| Post | Best Day | Best Time | Estimated Performance |
|------|----------|-----------|----------------------|
| Post 1 (AI Thought) | Tuesday | 8:00 AM | High - controversial topic |
| Post 2 (Portfolio) | Thursday | 10:00 AM | Medium-High - visual appeal |
| Post 3 (Checklist) | Tuesday | 1:00 PM | High - save-for-later content |
| Post 4 (Story) | Friday | 3:00 PM | Medium - weekend engagement |
| Post 5 (Poll) | Wednesday | 9:00 AM | High - easy engagement |

---

- [ ] Add relevant hashtags (remove company tags if posting personally)
- [ ] Schedule or queue for recommended times
- [ ] Prepare images for posts 2 (before/after mockups)

# LinkedIn Content Bank â€” Week 2

**Author:** Chicco Kabundji  
**Date Created:** February 21, 2026  
**Brands:** Pulse Graphix, Nexus AI, Invest Congo, Pulse Architects

---

## POST 1: Thought Leadership â€” AI & Design Industry Trend

**Platform:** LinkedIn  
**Language:** English  
**Type:** Thought Leadership  
**Target Brand:** Nexus AI

### Hook
ðŸ¤– AI won't replace designers. But designers who use AI will replace those who don't.

### Body
I've been testing AI web design tools for the past 6 months, and here's the uncomfortable truth nobody's talking about:

The debate isn't "Human vs Machine" anymore. It's "Enhanced Human vs Unenhanced Human."

**What's changing:**
â€¢ Design iteration speed: 10Ã— faster with AI prototyping
â€¢ Personalization at scale: What used to take weeks now takes hours
â€¢ Creative exploration: AI generates 50 variations while you sleep

**What's NOT changing:**
â€¢ Strategy still requires human insight
â€¢ Client relationships can't be automated
â€¢ Taste and judgment remain deeply human skills

The designers thriving in 2026 aren't the ones fighting AI. They're the ones learning to dance with it.

**My prediction:** By 2027, "AI-fluent designer" won't be a specialty â€” it'll be table stakes.

Are you upskilling or watching from the sidelines?

### Hashtags
#AIDesign #WebDesign #DesignThinking #ArtificialIntelligence #FutureOfWork #DigitalTransformation #DesignerLife #CreativeTech

---

## POST 2: Thought Leadership â€” Web Design Market Evolution

**Platform:** LinkedIn  
**Language:** French  
**Type:** Thought Leadership  
**Target Brand:** Pulse Graphix

### Hook
ðŸŽ¯ Pourquoi 70% des entreprises refont leur site web tous les 2-3 ans ?

### Body

## POST 7: Behind-the-Scenes â€” Client Challenge

**Platform:** LinkedIn  
**Language:** English  
**Type:** Behind-the-Scenes Story  
**Target Brand:** Nexus AI

### Hook
ðŸ’¬ "Can you build this by Friday?" â€” A client story about impossible deadlines (and what I learned)

### Body
Last month, a startup founder called me in panic.

Their investor pitch was Monday. Their website? A broken WordPress disaster from 2019.

"We need a complete redesign by Friday. Can you do it?"

**Old me would have said:** "Sure!" (then panic-worked 72 hours straight)

**2026 me said:** "No. But here's what we CAN do."

**The conversation:**
ME: "What's the actual goal for Monday's pitch?"
CLIENT: "Investors need to see we're legit and understand what we do."
ME: "Do you need a full website or a killer landing page?"
CLIENT: "...I guess just a landing page?"

**What we did in 3 days:**
âœ… 1 high-converting landing page (not 15 pages)
âœ… AI-generated hero visuals (Midjourney + editing)
âœ… Clear value prop + 3-point pitch
âœ… Email capture for "early access"
âœ… Mobile-optimized, fast-loading

**What we DIDN'T waste time on:**
âŒ Blog (no one reads startup blogs pre-launch anyway)
âŒ About page with every team member's biography
âŒ Complex navigation
âŒ Custom animations

**The result:**
They nailed the pitch. Investors loved the clarity.

3 weeks later, we built the full site â€” with actual user feedback to guide decisions.

**The lesson:**
Sometimes "impossible deadline" is code for "unclear priorities."

Instead of working faster, ask:
â€¢ What's the real outcome you need?
â€¢ What's the minimum viable version?
â€¢ What can wait until we have real data?

Speed is good. Clarity is better.

Have you ever turned down a project to save it from itself?

### Hashtags
#WebDesign #ClientStories #StartupLife #Entrepreneurship #ProjectManagement #DesignThinking #LessonsLearned #FreelanceLife #DigitalAgency

## POST 8: Behind-the-Scenes â€” Lessons Learned

**Platform:** LinkedIn  
**Language:** English  
**Type:** Behind-the-Scenes Reflection  
**Target Brand:** Pulse Graphix

### Hook
ðŸ§  I wasted $8,000 building the wrong website. Here's what I learned.

### Body
2024. A retail client came to us wanting "a Shopify store like [famous brand]."

We said yes. Built it. Launched it.

**3 months later:** 0.4% conversion rate. They were bleeding money on ads going nowhere.

**What went wrong?**

We built what they ASKED for, not what they NEEDED.

**The mistakes:**
1. We copied a brand with $2M ad budget and brand recognition
2. We didn't question their product-market fit
3. We focused on design, ignored customer research
4. We assumed "more features = better" (it never is)

**What we SHOULD have done:**
âœ… Week 1: Interview 10 target customers before touching Figma
âœ… Week 2: Analyze top 5 competitors â€” what converts, what doesn't
âœ… Week 3: Build a minimal MVP (10 products, basic design)
âœ… Week 4: Launch, track, learn
âœ… Month 2-3: Iterate based on DATA, not opinions

**The turnaround:**
We rebuilt from scratch. This time:
â€¢ Simplified to 3 product categories (from 12)
â€¢ Added customer reviews front and center
â€¢ Changed hero message based on actual customer language
â€¢ Added trust badges (return policy, local delivery, real testimonials)

**New results after 6 weeks:**
ðŸ“Š Conversion rate: 3.2% (8Ã— improvement)
ðŸ“Š Average order value: +47%
ðŸ“Š Customer support questions: -60% (clearer messaging)

**The real lesson:**
You're not paid to execute requests. You're paid to solve problems.

Next time a client says "I want X," my first question is:

**"What problem are you trying to solve?"**

Most expensive lesson of my career. Best investment in my skills.

What's a project failure that made you a better professional?

### Hashtags
#WebDesign #LessonsLearned #Entrepreneurship #EcommerceTips #ClientWork #DesignThinking #Failure #GrowthMindset #DigitalMarketing #Shopify

## USAGE NOTES

**Posting Schedule Recommendation:**
- Monday: Thought leadership (sets the tone for the week)
- Tuesday: Educational content (value-add)
- Wednesday: Portfolio showcase (proof)
- Thursday: Behind-the-scenes / Story (human connection)
- Friday: Poll or Hot Take (engagement boost)

**Engagement Strategy:**
- Respond to ALL comments within 24 hours
- Ask follow-up questions to commenters
- Share poll results in a follow-up post
- Tag relevant people/companies when appropriate (but don't overdo it)

**Content Mix Rationale:**
- 20% Thought leadership (positions as industry expert)
- 20% Educational (builds trust, provides value)
- 20% Portfolio/proof (demonstrates results)
- 20% Story/behind-the-scenes (relatability, authenticity)
- 20% Engagement (polls, hot takes â€” drives algorithm)

**Performance Tracking:**
Monitor these metrics per post:
- Impressions
- Engagement rate (likes + comments + shares / impressions)
- Click-through to website
- DM inquiries
- Profile views

Adjust future content based on what performs best!

files.name: social-media-templates-specs.md
files.content:
# Social Media Templates â€” Design Specifications
*Prepared: Feb 26, 2026 | For Kabundji to build in Canva/Figma*

---

## Master Brand Guidelines

### Color Palette
| Role | Hex | Usage |
|------|-----|-------|
| Primary Dark | #0D0D0D | Backgrounds |
| Primary Teal | #14B8A6 | Accent, CTAs, icons |
| Secondary Sky | #0EA5E9 | Gradients, highlights |
| Gold | #F59E0B | Revenue/growth elements |
| White | #FFFFFF | Text on dark |
| Muted | #888888 | Secondary text |

### Typography
- **Headlines:** Inter 700-900
- **Body:** Inter 400-500
- **Small/Captions:** Inter 300, uppercase, tracking wider

---

## Template 1: LinkedIn Carousel
**Dimensions:** 1080 x 1080px (square) or 1080 x 1350px (portrait)
**Format:** 5-7 slides

**Slide Structure:**
1. **Hook Slide:** Big number + problem statement
   - "73% des sites PME ne convertissent pas"
   - Dark bg (#0D0D0D), teal accent bar left

2-4. **Content Slides:** Tips numbered 1, 2, 3
   - Bullet points with teal icons
   - White text, generous whitespace

5. **CTA Slide:** "Voir mon portfolio â†’" with website
   - Gradient bg (teal to sky), white text

**Design Notes:**
- Consistent header bar with "Pulse Graphix" logo
- Page numbers bottom right (01/05...)
- Arrow icon "â†’" after each CTA

---

## Template 2: YouTube Thumbnail
**Dimensions:** 1280 x 720px
**Safe Zone:** 1280 x 420px (title must fit here)

**Layout:**
- **Left 60%:** Your photo (professional, looking at camera, confident)
- **Right 40%:** Big title text + small "Pulse Graphix" watermark
- **Background:** Dark gradient (#0D0D0D â†’ #1a1a1a) with subtle pattern
- **Accent:** Teal underline or corner element

**Title Treatment:**
- All caps, bold, white with subtle shadow
- Max 6 words
- Example: "CONSTRUIRE UN SITE EN 30 MIN"

**Watermark:** Bottom right, small Pulse Graphix logo, semi-transparent

---

## Template 3: TikTok Cover / Instagram Reels
**Dimensions:** 1080 x 1920px (9:16 vertical)

**Frame (15 sec video setup):**
- **0-3 sec:** Hook text + face
- **3-12 sec:** Screen recording/demo
- **12-15 sec:** CTA with handle

**Cover Frame:**
- Large emoji/illustration top center
- Big text: "3 ASTUCES SITES WEB"
- "Pulse Graphix" bottom, small
- Teal highlight marks on key words

---

## Template 4: Quote Card
**Dimensions:** 1080 x 1080px (square)

**Layout:**
- **Split:** Left 40% teal gradient box, Right 60% dark
- **Left:** Small "Pulse Graphix" vertical
- **Right:** Quote in white italic text
- **Bottom:** Author name + small headshot circle

**Quote Styling:**
- Large quotation mark in teal (top left of text area)
- Text: "Votre site web est votre meilleur vendeur. S'il dort, vous perdez des clients."
- Font size: 36-48px

---

## Template 5: Announcement / Launch
**Dimensions:** 1080 x 1350px (portrait for LinkedIn/IG)

**Structure:**
1. **Header:** "NOUVEAU" badge + date
2. **Main Visual:** Product screenshot or service illustration
3. **Headline:** 2-3 words, huge, bold
4. **Body:** 2-3 lines of details
5. **Footer:** CTA button + website

**Example â€” Template Launch:**
- Badge: "DISPONIBLE MAINTENANT" (teal bg)
- Visual: SaaS dashboard mockup
- Headline: "TEMPLATE SAAS" (gradient text)
- Body: "PrÃªt en 48h. 100% personnalisable."
- CTA: "VOIR LA DÃ‰MO â†’"

---

## Deliverable Checklist
- [ ] Template 1: LinkedIn carousel (5-7 slides)
- [ ] Template 2: YouTube thumbnail (3 variants)
- [ ] Template 3: TikTok cover (2 variants)
- [ ] Template 4: Quote card (3 quotes ready)
- [ ] Template 5: Announcement (2 variants)

**Tools:** Canva Pro or Figma
**Export:** PNG for images, PDF for carousels (or Canva link)

files.name: announcement-template.html
files.content:
ðŸ“¢ Announcement Template

High-impact promotional graphics for launches, events, and updates

ðŸ“ Core Dimensions

Canvas Dimensions
1080 Ã— 1350 pixels
Aspect Ratio
4:5 (Vertical)
Resolution
72 DPI
File Format
JPG or PNG
Primary Platform
Instagram Feed, Facebook
Safe Zone
1000 Ã— 1270 px (40px margins)

Why 4:5? Instagram's algorithm favors 4:5 vertical posts â€” they take up more screen real estate in feed, increasing visibility and engagement by up to 40% compared to square posts.

ðŸŽ¯ Layout Structure & CTA Placement

NEW LAUNCH
Announcement Headline
Supporting details and key information goes here in the center section.
CALL TO ACTION
1080 Ã— 1350 px (4:5 vertical)
CTA button: 1000px width Ã— 80-100px height, 60-80px from bottom

Three-Zone Layout:

  • Zone 1 - Header (Top 200-300px):
    • Eye-catching banner or background
    • Category label (e.g., "NEW", "LIMITED", "EVENT", "SALE")
    • Logo placement (if appropriate)
  • Zone 2 - Content (Middle 700-900px):
    • Main headline (3-6 words)
    • Supporting text (1-2 sentences, 20-30 words)
    • Key details (date, time, location, pricing if relevant)
    • Visual element (product image, illustration, icon)
  • Zone 3 - CTA (Bottom 150-200px):
    • Clear call-to-action button or text
    • 1000px width, 80-100px height, 60-80px from bottom edge
    • High contrast with background

ðŸŽ¨ Color Palettes by Company

Pulse Graphix

Primary Orange (CTA)
#FF6B35
Deep Blue (Headers)
#004E89
Charcoal (Text)
#1A1A1D
Off White (BG)
#F7F7F7

Nexus AI

Cyber Cyan (CTA)
#00D9FF
AI Purple (Headers)
#7B2CBF
Deep Space (BG)
#0A0E27
Hot Pink (Accent)
#FF0055

Invest Congo

Gold (CTA/Accent)
#FFD700
Forest Green (Headers)
#006B3F
Congo Red (Accent)
#C41E3A
Clean White (BG)
#FFFFFF

Pulse Architects

Architectural Gold (CTA)
#E8B923
Slate Blue (Headers)
#2C3E50
Light Stone (BG)
#ECF0F1
Accent Red
#E74C3C

âœï¸ Typography Recommendations

Category Label (Top Header)

  • Font: Montserrat Bold, Bebas Neue, or Oswald Bold
  • Size: 36-48px
  • Weight: Bold or Extra Bold
  • Letter Spacing: +2-4px (tracking for emphasis)
  • Color: White (if on colored header) or brand color
  • Examples: "NEW LAUNCH", "LIMITED TIME", "COMING SOON", "BIG NEWS"

Main Headline

  • Font: Montserrat Bold, Poppins Bold, or custom brand font
  • Size: 64-80px
  • Weight: Bold
  • Line Height: 1.2
  • Color: High contrast (dark on light, light on dark)
  • Max Length: 3-6 words (1-2 lines)

Supporting Text / Details

  • Font: Open Sans Regular, Roboto Regular
  • Size: 32-40px
  • Line Height: 1.5
  • Color: Medium contrast (#666 on white, rgba(255,255,255,0.8) on dark)
  • Max Length: 20-30 words (2-3 lines)

CTA Button Text

  • Font: Montserrat Bold or Poppins Semi-Bold
  • Size: 40-52px
  • Weight: Bold or Semi-Bold
  • Letter Spacing: +1-2px
  • Color: White (on colored button) or very high contrast
  • Max Length: 2-4 words (e.g., "LEARN MORE", "SHOP NOW", "REGISTER FREE")

Date/Time/Location Text

  • Font: Roboto Medium or Open Sans Semi-Bold
  • Size: 28-32px
  • Style: Often with icon (ðŸ“… calendar, ðŸ• clock, ðŸ“ pin)

ðŸ–²ï¸ CTA Button Best Practices

CTA Button Specs:

  • Dimensions: 1000px width Ã— 80-100px height
  • Position: 60-80px from bottom, horizontally centered
  • Border Radius: 8-16px (rounded corners for modern look)
  • Color: Primary brand color or high-contrast accent
  • Shadow: 0px 4px 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.15) for depth
  • Hover State (if interactive): Slightly darker shade or subtle glow

Effective CTA Text Examples:

SHOP NOW
LEARN MORE
SIGN UP FREE
GET STARTED
CLAIM OFFER
REGISTER TODAY
JOIN WAITLIST
DOWNLOAD NOW
BOOK A CALL

CTA Writing Rules:

  • âœ… Use action verbs (Shop, Learn, Get, Claim, Join)
  • âœ… Create urgency when appropriate (TODAY, NOW, LIMITED)
  • âœ… Be specific (not just "Click Here")
  • âœ… Keep it short (2-4 words maximum)
  • âŒ Avoid vague text ("More Info")
  • âŒ Don't use all lowercase (looks weak)

ðŸ–¼ï¸ Example Asset Description

Example: Nexus AI "Free Webinar" Announcement

Announcement: "Free AI Web Design Webinar â€” Feb 28, 2026"

Layout & Elements:

  • Zone 1 - Header (Top 280px):
    • Background: Gradient from #7B2CBF (top) to #00D9FF (middle)
    • Category text: "FREE WEBINAR" (Bebas Neue, 42px, white, centered, 60px from top, +3px letter-spacing)
    • Nexus AI logo: Top-left corner (80px height, 40px margins, white version)
  • Zone 2 - Content (Middle 890px):
    • Background: White
    • Headline: "Master AI Web Design in 60 Minutes" (Montserrat Bold, 72px, #0A0E27, center-aligned, 60px from header)
    • Supporting text: "Learn how AI can 10Ã— your design workflow â€” live demonstration + Q&A" (Open Sans Regular, 36px, #666, center-aligned, 30px below headline)
    • Event details (stacked, center-aligned, 40px below supporting text):
      • ðŸ“… "Friday, February 28, 2026" (Roboto Medium, 32px, #333)
      • ðŸ• "3:00 PM CET" (Roboto Medium, 32px, #333)
    • Visual element: Stylized laptop illustration showing AI interface (400Ã—300px, centered, 40px below event details)
  • Zone 3 - CTA (Bottom 180px):
    • CTA button: 1000px Ã— 90px, 70px from bottom, centered
    • Background: #00D9FF (cyan)
    • Border radius: 12px
    • Shadow: 0px 6px 16px rgba(0, 217, 255, 0.3)
    • Text: "REGISTER FREE" (Montserrat Bold, 48px, white, +2px letter-spacing)

Visual Style: Clean, professional, high-energy. Gradient header draws attention, white middle provides clarity, cyan CTA stands out.

ðŸ“‹ Announcement Types & Variations

1. Product/Service Launch

  • Header: "NEW LAUNCH" or "INTRODUCING"
  • Content: Product name, key benefit, visual mockup
  • CTA: "SHOP NOW", "LEARN MORE", "PRE-ORDER"

2. Event Announcement

  • Header: Event type (WEBINAR, WORKSHOP, CONFERENCE)
  • Content: Event title, date/time, speaker/topic
  • CTA: "REGISTER FREE", "SAVE YOUR SEAT", "GET TICKETS"

3. Limited-Time Offer

  • Header: "LIMITED TIME" or "FLASH SALE"
  • Content: Offer details, discount amount, expiration date
  • CTA: "CLAIM OFFER", "SHOP SALE", "GET 50% OFF"

4. Company Update/News

  • Header: "BIG NEWS" or "ANNOUNCEMENT"
  • Content: Update summary, implications, next steps
  • CTA: "READ MORE", "LEARN ABOUT IT", "SEE WHAT'S NEW"

5. Coming Soon Teaser

  • Header: "COMING SOON"
  • Content: Teaser text, launch date, sneak peek visual
  • CTA: "JOIN WAITLIST", "BE THE FIRST", "GET NOTIFIED"

âœ¨ Design Elements & Enhancements

  • âœ… Visual Hierarchy: Header â†’ Headline â†’ Details â†’ CTA (top to bottom flow)
  • âœ… Icons: Use simple icons for date/time/location (32-40px size)
  • âœ… Product Images: If showcasing product, use high-quality PNG with transparent background
  • âœ… Shapes/Frames: Circles, rounded rectangles to frame key elements
  • âœ… Patterns: Subtle background patterns (dots, lines, grid) at 5-10% opacity
  • âœ… Badges: "NEW", "FREE", "50% OFF" badges in corner or on header
  • âŒ Avoid Clutter: Don't try to fit too much information â€” focus on key message
  • âŒ Avoid Weak CTAs: Button must be prominent and impossible to miss

âœ… Pre-Flight Checklist

  • â˜ Dimensions are exactly 1080Ã—1350px (4:5 aspect ratio)
  • â˜ Content stays within safe zone (40px margins)
  • â˜ Clear three-zone structure (header, content, CTA)
  • â˜ Headline is 3-6 words maximum
  • â˜ Supporting text is under 30 words
  • â˜ CTA button is prominent (1000Ã—80-100px, bottom placement)
  • â˜ CTA text is action-oriented and specific (2-4 words)
  • â˜ High contrast throughout (text readable at all sizes)
  • â˜ Brand colors used consistently
  • â˜ Logo/branding present but not dominating
  • â˜ All critical info (date, time, offer) clearly visible
  • â˜ No typos or grammatical errors
  • â˜ File format correct (JPG or PNG)

ðŸ’¡ Pro Tips for High-Converting Announcements

  • ðŸŽ¯ Lead with Value: Headline should answer "What's in it for me?"
  • âš¡ Create Urgency: Limited time, spots, or availability increases action
  • ðŸŽ¨ Make CTA Pop: Use contrasting color that draws the eye instantly
  • ðŸ“± Mobile-First: Test on phone â€” 4:5 vertical is perfect for Instagram mobile feed
  • ðŸ”¥ A/B Test: Try different headlines, colors, CTAs to see what converts best
  • âœ¨ Keep It Simple: One clear message beats five competing messages

ðŸ“Š LinkedIn Carousel Template

Professional carousel design specifications for maximum engagement

ðŸ“ Core Dimensions

Slide Dimensions
1080 Ã— 1080 pixels
Aspect Ratio
1:1 (Square)
Number of Slides
5-10 slides (optimal: 7-8)
File Format
PDF or Image Sequence (PNG/JPG)
Resolution
72 DPI (web optimized)
Max File Size
100 MB total (PDF method)

ðŸŽ¯ Safe Zones & Layout Grid

1080 Ã— 1080 px outer boundary
Safe zone: 1000 Ã— 1000 px (40px margin all sides)

Critical Guidelines:

  • Content Safe Zone: Keep all text, logos, and important elements within 40px from edges (1000Ã—1000px safe area)
  • Grid System: 18-column grid (60px per column) for consistent alignment
  • Logo Placement: Top-left or top-right corner, minimum 50px from edges
  • Slide Numbers: Bottom-right corner (e.g., "3/7"), 30px from bottom-right corner
  • Navigation Arrows: LinkedIn overlays arrows on left/right edges â€” avoid placing text there

âœï¸ Typography Recommendations

Primary Headlines (Slide Titles)

  • Font: Montserrat Bold, Poppins Bold, or Inter Bold
  • Size: 64-80px
  • Line Height: 1.2
  • Color: High contrast with background (black on light, white on dark)
  • Max Characters: 40-50 characters per line (2-3 lines max)

Body Text

  • Font: Open Sans Regular, Roboto Regular, or Inter Regular
  • Size: 32-40px
  • Line Height: 1.5
  • Max Lines: 6-8 lines per slide

Supporting Text / Captions

  • Font: Same as body, but lighter weight or smaller size
  • Size: 24-28px
  • Use For: Sources, footnotes, slide numbers

ðŸ“‹ Carousel Structure Best Practices

  1. Slide 1 (Hook): Eye-catching title, question, or bold statement
  2. Slides 2-6 (Content): One key point per slide, use numbers or icons
  3. Slide 7 (Summary): Recap key takeaways
  4. Slide 8 (CTA): Call-to-action (Follow, Comment, Link in bio, DM)

ðŸ–¼ï¸ Example Asset Description

Slide 1 Example: "5 Secrets to 10X Your Website Conversions"

Layout: Centered text with gradient background (Nexus AI purple-to-cyan gradient)

Elements:

  • Top-right: Nexus AI logo (80Ã—80px, white version)
  • Center: Headline "5 Secrets to" (Montserrat Bold, 72px, white)
  • Center: "10X Your Website" (Montserrat Bold, 80px, white)
  • Center: "Conversions" (Montserrat Bold, 80px, cyan #00D9FF accent)
  • Bottom-center: Small icon or emoji (ðŸ“ˆ)
  • Bottom-right: "1/8" slide counter (28px, white, 50% opacity)

Visual Style: Modern, clean, high-contrast. Gradient from #7B2CBF (top) to #0A0E27 (bottom) with subtle grid pattern overlay.

âœ… Pre-Flight Checklist

  • â˜ All slides are exactly 1080Ã—1080px
  • â˜ Content stays within safe zone (40px margins)
  • â˜ Text is readable at thumbnail size (test at 200px wide)
  • â˜ Consistent branding across all slides
  • â˜ Slide numbers included (1/7, 2/7, etc.)
  • â˜ Clear progression/narrative flow
  • â˜ Final slide has clear CTA
  • â˜ File size under 100MB

Photo Background
Photo + color overlay (70-80%)

ðŸ–¼ï¸ Example Asset Description

Example: Nexus AI Inspirational Quote

Quote: "AI doesn't replace creativity. It amplifies it."

Layout & Elements:

  • Background: Diagonal gradient from #7B2CBF (top-left) to #00D9FF (bottom-right)
  • Quote Marks: Large opening quote (140px, Playfair Display, white, 30% opacity) in top-left corner at 60px from edges
  • Main Quote:
    • Text: "AI doesn't replace creativity. It amplifies it." (Montserrat Bold, 64px, white)
    • Center-aligned vertically and horizontally
    • Line breaks: "AI doesn't replace / creativity. / It amplifies it."
    • 2px subtle text shadow (rgba(0,0,0,0.2))
  • Attribution: "â€” Nexus AI" (Montserrat Regular, 32px, white, 90% opacity, bottom-center, 70px from bottom)
  • Logo: Small Nexus AI icon (70px) in bottom-right corner, 50px from edges, 80% opacity
  • Visual Accent: Subtle circuit pattern overlay across entire background (5% white opacity, blend mode: soft-light)

Visual Style: Modern, tech-forward, inspiring. High contrast ensures readability. Gradient adds depth and energy.

âœ¨ Design Best Practices

  • âœ… Keep It Short: 15-20 words maximum â€” quote cards are meant to be read quickly
  • âœ… High Contrast: Quote must be instantly readable â€” no squinting
  • âœ… Breathing Room: Don't cram text â€” white space (or background space) is your friend
  • âœ… Consistent Branding: Use brand colors and fonts for recognition
  • âœ… Subtle Logo: Logo should be present but not competing with the quote
  • âœ… Shareable: Make it so good people want to repost it
  • âŒ Avoid Clutter: Don't add unnecessary decorative elements
  • âŒ Avoid Bad Typography: No comic sans, no overly decorative fonts that hurt readability
  • âŒ Avoid Low Contrast: Light grey text on white = invisible

ðŸ’¡ Quote Selection Tips

Great Quotes Are:

  • Short: Under 20 words (fits comfortably on 1080Ã—1080px)
  • Impactful: Makes you think or feel something
  • Relevant: Aligned with your brand values and audience interests
  • Shareable: People want to repost it to their stories/feeds
  • Authentic: Either original or properly attributed

Quote Types That Perform Well:

  • Inspirational/motivational quotes
  • Industry wisdom (design, AI, business)
  • Client testimonials (with permission)
  • Company mission/vision statements
  • Thought-provoking questions
  • Before/after mindset shifts

âœ… Pre-Flight Checklist

  • â˜ Dimensions are exactly 1080Ã—1080px
  • â˜ Quote is under 120 characters (20 words max)
  • â˜ Text stays within 80px margins (920Ã—920px safe zone)
  • â˜ Font size is large enough to read on mobile (52px minimum)
  • â˜ High contrast between text and background (readable at a glance)
  • â˜ Proper attribution included (if using someone else's quote)
  • â˜ Brand logo or name is subtly present
  • â˜ Background uses brand colors
  • â˜ No typos or grammatical errors
  • â˜ Saved in correct format (PNG or JPG)

files.content:
ðŸ“± TikTok/Reels Cover Template

Vertical video cover design for feed preview optimization

ðŸ“ Core Dimensions

Canvas Dimensions
1080 Ã— 1920 pixels
Aspect Ratio
9:16 (Vertical)
Resolution
72 DPI (web optimized)
File Format
JPG, PNG (for static covers)
Feed Preview Size
Variable (middle ~600px height visible)
Max File Size
5 MB (recommended < 2 MB)

ðŸŽ¯ Feed Safe Zone (Critical!)

Profile Info Area
FEED PREVIEW
SAFE ZONE
(Middle 600px)
â¤ï¸
ðŸ’¬
âž¤
ðŸŽµ
Caption text appears here...
1080 Ã— 1920 px full canvas
Feed safe zone: Center ~600px height (vertically centered)

Critical Guidelines:

  • Feed Preview Zone: Center your key visual and text in the MIDDLE 600px height (approx. pixels 660-1260 from top)
  • Top Area: Top ~180px can be obscured by profile picture, username, and "Follow" button
  • Bottom Area: Bottom ~480px contains caption, engagement buttons (like, comment, share), and audio info
  • Right Edge: Right ~60px reserved for vertical button stack â€” avoid placing text here
  • The Golden Rule: Your cover must be compelling when viewed in grid/feed format (middle section only)
ðŸ“± Mobile-First Design: 99% of TikTok/Reels views happen on mobile. Always design and test at mobile scale. What looks good on desktop might be invisible on a phone.

ðŸŽ¨ Color Palettes by Company

Pulse Graphix

Primary Orange
#FF6B35
Deep Blue
#004E89
Bright White
#F7F7F7
Accent Gold
#FFD700

Nexus AI

Cyber Cyan
#00D9FF
AI Purple
#7B2CBF
Hot Pink
#FF0055
Pure White
#FFFFFF

Invest Congo

Gold
#FFD700
Forest Green
#006B3F
Congo Red
#C41E3A
Clean White
#FFFFFF

Pulse Architects

Slate Blue
#2C3E50
Architectural Gold
#E8B923
Light Stone
#ECF0F1
Accent Red
#E74C3C

âœï¸ Typography Recommendations

Primary Headline (2-4 Words)

  • Font: Montserrat Black, Bebas Neue, or Anton
  • Size: 100-140px (LARGE for mobile visibility)
  • Weight: Extra Bold / Black
  • Stroke: 8-12px contrasting outline (white on dark, black on light)
  • Placement: Centered vertically in feed safe zone (middle 600px)
  • Line Height: 1.1 (tight spacing for impact)
  • Max Lines: 2-3 lines maximum

Secondary Text (Optional)

  • Font: Open Sans Bold or Roboto Bold
  • Size: 48-64px
  • Use For: Supporting context, episode number, category
  • Placement: Above or below headline, within safe zone

Branding / Logo

  • Size: 60-90px height
  • Placement: Top-left or top-center (if above safe zone) OR bottom-left (if below safe zone)
  • Margin: 40px from edges
  • Opacity: Consider 70-80% opacity if overlaying video content
âš ï¸ Text Readability: Vertical videos scroll fast. If someone can't read your text in 0.5 seconds, it's too complex. Keep it BOLD, SHORT, and HIGH CONTRAST.

ðŸ“± Layout Grid & Composition

Vertical Zones (1080px width Ã— 1920px height):

  • Zone 1 (Top 0-660px): Background/ambient visual only â€” can be obscured by UI
  • Zone 2 (Middle 660-1260px): ðŸŽ¯ FEED SAFE ZONE â€” Place all critical content here
  • Zone 3 (Bottom 1260-1920px): Secondary content, branding â€” partially obscured by caption/buttons

Horizontal Grid:

  • Use 12-column grid (90px per column)
  • Center content in columns 2-11 (leaving 90px margins on left/right)
  • Right column 12 reserved for engagement buttons â€” avoid text

ðŸ–¼ï¸ Example Asset Description

Example: "5-Second Website Hack" Reels Cover

Layout: Vertical gradient background with centered text in feed safe zone

Elements (Top to Bottom):

  • Zone 1 (Top):
    • Gradient background: #7B2CBF to #FF0055 (top to middle)
    • Subtle animated code particles floating upward (if video)
    • Nexus AI logo (70px height) top-left corner, 40px margins, 70% opacity
  • Zone 2 (Middle - SAFE ZONE):
    • Main text: "5-SECOND" (Bebas Neue, 120px, white with black 10px stroke)
    • Main text: "WEBSITE" (Bebas Neue, 130px, cyan #00D9FF with black 10px stroke)
    • Main text: "HACK" (Bebas Neue, 140px, white with black 10px stroke)
    • Small emoji below text: "âš¡" (80px)
    • All text center-aligned, vertically stacked
  • Zone 3 (Bottom):
    • Continue gradient to #0A0E27 (dark space)
    • Small floating UI mockup elements (subtle, not competing with text)

Visual Style: Bold, energetic, optimized for quick scroll-stopping power. Text is 100% readable even when caption and buttons overlay bottom portion.

ðŸŽ¬ Platform-Specific Considerations

TikTok vs Instagram Reels:

TikTok
â€¢ Bottom UI is more prominent
â€¢ Feed grid shows square crop of middle
â€¢ Profile overlay covers more of top
â€¢ Recommended: Center content lower (pixels 700-1200)
Instagram Reels
â€¢ Cleaner interface, less overlay
â€¢ Feed grid shows full vertical preview
â€¢ More top space visible
â€¢ Recommended: Can use full middle 600px zone

Cover vs Video:

  • Static Cover: Used when uploading video â€” shows in feed before play. Keep simple, bold text.
  • First Frame: If no custom cover, first frame of video is used. Design your intro frame following these specs.
  • Motion: If video cover, subtle motion (floating elements, slow zoom) increases engagement.

âœ¨ Design Elements for Vertical Format

  • âœ… Vertical Emphasis: Stack elements vertically, not horizontally
  • âœ… Center Alignment: Keep key elements center-aligned for symmetry
  • âœ… Bold Shapes: Large circles, arrows, or boxes to frame content
  • âœ… Gradients: Vertical gradients work beautifully (top-to-bottom color flow)
  • âœ… Face Placement: If including a face, center it in feed safe zone, 300-400px height
  • âœ… Emojis: 1-2 large emojis (70-100px) for emotion/context
  • âœ… Minimal Text: 2-5 words maximum â€” this is vertical video, not a blog post
  • âŒ Avoid Horizontal Layouts: Don't try to fit horizontal website mockups â€” won't read well

âœ… Pre-Flight Checklist

  • â˜ Dimensions are exactly 1080Ã—1920px (9:16 vertical)
  • â˜ Main content centered in middle 600px (feed safe zone)
  • â˜ Text readable when bottom 480px is covered by caption/UI
  • â˜ Right 60px clear of text (engagement buttons area)
  • â˜ Top 180px doesn't contain critical info (profile overlay)
  • â˜ Text is LARGE (100px+ font size)
  • â˜ High contrast (text has stroke/outline)
  • â˜ Maximum 2-5 words of text
  • â˜ File size under 2 MB (for fast loading)
  • â˜ Tested at mobile phone size (not just desktop)

ðŸ’¡ Pro Tips

  • ðŸŽ¯ Stop-the-Scroll Test: Would this make YOU stop scrolling? If not, redesign.
  • ðŸ“± Phone Test: Always view your cover on an actual phone before publishing.
  • âš¡ 0.5 Second Rule: If message isn't clear in half a second, simplify.
  • ðŸŽ¨ Contrast is King: When in doubt, make it MORE contrasty.
  • ðŸ”¥ Curiosity Gap: Tease the value, don't give it all away â€” make them watch.

Title safe zone: Left 640px Ã— 660px height (avoid bottom 60px)

Critical Guidelines:

  • Title Safe Zone: Keep main text and CTAs in the LEFT 640px Ã— 660px area (left half, avoiding bottom 60px)
  • Bottom-Right Reserved: YouTube places timestamp (bottom-right corner, ~100Ã—30px) â€” avoid text here
  • Top-Right Reserved: "Watch Later" icon appears on hover (~40Ã—40px from top-right)
  • Face Placement: If using a person, position face in LEFT or CENTER â€” never right edge (gets cut in mobile)
  • Mobile Preview: Test at 320Ã—180px â€” text must still be readable
âš ï¸ Mobile Consideration: On mobile, thumbnails display at very small sizes. The left portion is most visible. Place your most important elements (text, faces, key visuals) on the LEFT HALF of the canvas.

ðŸŽ¨ Color Palettes by Company

âš¡ Contrast Specifications

YouTube thumbnails compete with hundreds of other videos. HIGH CONTRAST is essential for visibility.

âœ… GOOD CONTRAST

BLACK TEXT ON BRIGHT YELLOW

WCAG AAA Rating: 19.56:1

âŒ POOR CONTRAST

GREY ON GREY

WCAG Rating: 2.1:1 (Fails)

Contrast Best Practices:

  • Minimum Ratio: 7:1 for text (WCAG AAA standard)
  • Text Stroke: Add 8-12px white or black stroke around text for readability on any background
  • Background Split: Use contrasting halves (e.g., bright left, dark right) to separate elements
  • Avoid: Light text on light backgrounds, dark on dark
  • Test: Convert thumbnail to grayscale â€” if elements disappear, contrast is too low

High-Impact Color Combinations:

  • Black text + Yellow/Orange background
  • White text + Dark blue/purple background
  • White text with black stroke + Any vibrant background
  • Complementary colors: Blue/Orange, Purple/Yellow, Red/Green

âœï¸ Typography Recommendations

Primary Text (3-5 Words Max)

  • Font: Bebas Neue, Montserrat Black, Impact, or Oswald Bold
  • Size: 120-180px (HUGE for mobile visibility)
  • Weight: Extra Bold / Black
  • Stroke: 10-15px white or black outline
  • Shadow: 5px drop shadow for depth (offset: 5px, blur: 10px)
  • Color: High contrast with background
  • Max Characters: 20-30 characters total (shorter is better)

Secondary Text (Optional)

  • Font: Same as primary but lighter weight
  • Size: 60-80px
  • Use For: Supporting detail, context

Branding / Logo

  • Size: 80-120px height
  • Placement: Bottom-left or top-left corner
  • Margin: 40px from edges

ðŸ–¼ï¸ Example Asset Description

Example: "AI Web Design in 5 Minutes" Tutorial Thumbnail

Layout: Split background â€” Left bright cyan gradient, Right dark space with floating UI elements

Elements:

  • Left Side (Title Safe):
    • Text: "AI WEB" (Bebas Neue, 160px, white with black 12px stroke)
    • Text: "DESIGN" (Bebas Neue, 160px, white with black 12px stroke)
    • Text: "IN 5 MIN" (Bebas Neue, 140px, hot pink #FF0055 with white 12px stroke)
  • Right Side:
    • Mockup of laptop screen showing AI interface (angled 15Â° for depth)
    • Floating UI cards with glow effect
  • Face Placement: Small circular headshot (200Ã—200px) in bottom-left, overlapping split
  • Logo: Nexus AI logo top-left corner (100px height, 40px margins)
  • Arrow/Emoji: Pointing arrow "âžœ" between text and laptop (80px, white)

Visual Style: Modern, energetic, high contrast. Gradient from #00D9FF to #7B2CBF on left. Dark #0A0E27 on right with subtle grid pattern.

ðŸŽ¨ Design Elements to Boost CTR

  • âœ… Faces: Human faces (especially with exaggerated expressions) increase CTR by 30%+
  • âœ… Arrows: Pointing to key elements directs viewer attention
  • âœ… Emojis: 1-2 large emojis (80-120px) add emotion and context
  • âœ… Numbers: "7 Tips" or "Step 3" create clear expectations
  • âœ… Before/After: Split images showing transformation
  • âœ… Questions: "Why?" or "How?" creates curiosity
  • âœ… Circles/Boxes: Highlight important areas with bright circles or boxes
  • âŒ Avoid Clutter: Max 3-4 elements total â€” keep it simple

âœ… Pre-Flight Checklist

  • â˜ Dimensions are exactly 1280Ã—720px
  • â˜ File size under 2 MB
  • â˜ Main text in LEFT 640px (title safe zone)
  • â˜ Bottom-right 100Ã—60px clear (timestamp area)
  • â˜ Text readable at 320Ã—180px mobile size
  • â˜ High contrast ratio (7:1 minimum)
  • â˜ Text has stroke/outline for readability
  • â˜ Logo visible but not dominating
  • â˜ Maximum 3-5 words of text
  • â˜ Saved in JPG/PNG format
